note_models.name: Cloze

fields:
Diabetes Mellitus:

A term for several diseases of abnormal {{c1::carbohydrate}} metabolism that are characterized by {{c1::hyperglycaemia}}.
Associated with relative or absolute impairment of insulin secretion by the islet cells of the {{c1::pancreas}}, along with varying degrees of peripheral resistance to the action of insulin.

Normal Carbohydrate Metabolism

•Blood glucose levels are normally maintained within a relatively narrow range ({{c1::4}}-{{c1::8}} mmol/L)
•This ensures that glucose is available as
–an {{c1::energy}} source (oxidised to H2O and CO2 yielding energy in the from of ATP)
–a precursor to complex {{c1::carbohydrates}}, proteins and {{c1::lipids}}
•On eating
–Complex carbohydrates are {{c1::hydrolysed}} to simple sugars (including glucose, fructose & galactose) that are absorbed through the small {{c1::intestine}} into the bloodstream.
–The rise in blood glucose stimulates insulin release from the pancreas.
–Insulin stimulates tissues to use the excess blood glucose:
•Activating glucose uptake into {{c1::muscle}} & adipose tissue
•Activating glycogen synthesis & inhibiting {{c1::glycogenolysis}} in muscle & liver cells
•Inhibiting gluconeogenesis
–Blood glucose levels fall

Normal Carbohydrate Metabolism

•Between meals
–As blood glucose levels fall insulin secretion by the pancreas slows and glucagon is released. The impact of this change to the hormonal milieu is:
–{{c1::Gluconeogenesis}} and glycogenolysis are activated to maintain blood glucose levels
•In prolonged fasting
–Lipids become an increasingly important energy source
–Fatty acids are released from adipose tissue ({{c1::lipolysis}}) and these can be used as an energy source by a variety of tissues (β-{{c1::oxidation}})
–Fatty acids cannot cross the blood brain barrier. When blood glucose levels are low, liver cells partially metabolise fatty acids releasing {{c1::ketone}} bodies into the bloodstream. {{c1::Ketone}} bodies can cross the blood brain barrier & can be taken up by brain cells as an energy source.

Deficiency/Resistance to Insulin

•Without insulin glucose is not taken up by muscle & adipose tissue
•{{c1::Glycogenolysis}} is activated in liver and muscle
•{{c1::Proteins}} are catabolised for energy & gluconeogenesis in many tissues
•Blood glucose levels rise
•Fatty acids are released into the bloodstream
–used as an energy source
–triglycerides resynthesized in {{c1::liver}} & repackaged into {{c1::lipoproteins}} (increased risk of atherosclerosis)
–Fatty acids are partially metabolised to ketone bodies that can be taken up as an energy source by brain cells

Symptoms associated with hyperglycaemia and glycosuria

•{{c1::Polyuria}}
–Filtered glucose exceeds tubular reabsorption threshold
–Osmotic diuresis created by glucose in urine
•{{c1::Polydipsia}}
–Combination of hyperglycaemia and water loss in urine result in plasma {{c1::hyperosmolality}}
–Hypertonicity is detected by specialised {{c1::hypothalamic}} cells (osmoreceptors). These osmoreceptors, along with angiotensin II, released secondary to volume depletion, stimulate thirst centres
•Weight loss
–Glycosuria and excess utilisation of {{c1::fat}} and protein as energy source
•Fatigue and hunger
–Inability of blood glucose to enter cells for {{c1::glycolysis}}

Diagnosing Diabetes Mellitus

Diagnosing diabetes mellitus is based on demonstrating hyperglycaemia through:
1. Diabetes {{c1::symptoms}} (polyuria, polydipsia and unexplained weight loss) plus:
a random {{c1::venous}} plasma glucose concentration > 11.1 mmol/L
  or
a fasting plasma glucose concentration > {{c1::7.0}} mmol/L
  or
plasma glucose concentration > {{c1::11.1}} mmol/L two hours after {{c1::75g}} anhydrous glucose in an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT).
2. With no symptoms diagnosis requires elevated glucose levels on at least {{c1::two}} occasions
3. An HbA1c of >{{c1::48}} mmol/mol
Note: None of these tests are specific for type of diabetes. Type is usually established based on clinical presentation.

Plasma Glucose

•Plasma is blood minus the cellular constituents (e.g. red blood cells, white blood cells and {{c1::platelets}})
•Important pre-analytical issues in ensuring accurate plasma glucose levels
–Clarity on patient state (fasting, 2 hour post glucose load, random)
•Critical to document time and fasting state of patient for accurate interpretation
–Specimen tube must prevent blood clotting
•If a clot forms, it may be more difficult to get a clean separation of the cells from the plasma
•To prevent clotting the collection tubes we use contain {{c1::oxalate}} salts. {{c1::Oxalate}} prevents clotting by forming {{c1::insoluble}} complexes with the calcium in the blood which is required for clotting
–Specimen tube must prevent {{c1::glycolysis}}
•Blood cells will continue to metabolise glucose in vitro
•Blood tubes for measuring glucose contain sodium {{c1::fluoride}} to inhibit enzymes involved in {{c1::glycolysis}}.

Hb A1c

•Proteins are continuously undergoing non-enzymatic chemically modification by glucose ({{c1::glycation}})
–Results in advanced glycation products (AGE) which may contribute to {{c1::microvascular}} and macrovascular complications of diabetes
•Hb A1c is formed by the glycation of the N-terminal {{c1::valine}} residue of each {{c1::β}}-chain of Hb A with glucose
•Formation of Hb A1c is essentially {{c1::irreversible}}
•The concentration in the blood depends on the lifespan of the red blood cell (average 120 days) and the blood glucose concentration
•It therefore reflects the integrated value for blood glucose over the preceding 6-8 weeks

largely reflects glycaemic control.
Can be expressed as percentage or mmol/mol

HbA1c in diagnosis

•DCCT units for Hb A1c were given as a % of Hb that is glycated
•We now use IFCC units (mmol of Hb A1c per mol of Hb A)
•Hb A1c has been accepted as a diagnostic indicator of diabetes mellitus at >{{c1::48}} mmol/mol•Caution required with interpretation because of:
–Shortened {{c1::RBC}} lifespan could result in a ↓ Hb A1c
•{{c1::Haemolytic}} disease
•Recent significant blood loss
–Lengthened {{c1::RBC}} lifespan could result in a ↑ HbA1c
•{{c1::Iron}} deficiency anaemia
–Haemoglobin variants (e.g. Hb S, Hb F, Hb C) can interfere with RBC lifespan, Hb glycation & analytical methods
{{c1::Sickle cell trait}} can interfere with accuracies in measuring and diagnosing diabetes with HbA1C.

Glycosuria

•Glycosuria (or glucosuria) is excretion of glucose in the urine
•How diabetes (‘to pass through’) mellitus (‘honey-sweet’) got its name!
•Filtered glucose is normally reabsorbed in the {{c1::proximal}} renal tubule
•However, the renal threshold for glucose reabsorption is ~{{c1::10}} mmol/L & if blood glucose is higher than this, glucose will be present in the urine
•Testing for glycosuria is not an accepted way of diagnosing diabetes
–Not {{c1::sensitive}}
•moderate {{c1::hyperglycaemia}} may not result in glycosuria
–Not specific
•renal threshold for glucose reabsorption is {{c1::variable}}
•some people, especially {{c1::pregnant}} women and children, excrete glucose with relatively normal blood glucose

Diabetes Risk States

•Impaired Fasting Glycaemia/Glucose
–Fasting glucose {{c1::5}}.6-{{c1::7.0}} mmol/l
–Suggests {{c1::hepatic}} insulin resistance
–Associated with a markedly increased risk of developing type {{c1::II}} diabetes mellitus
•{{c1::Impaired}} Glucose Tolerance
–OGTT 2h glucose {{c1::7.8}}-11.0 mmol/l
–Suggests {{c1::muscle}} insulin resistance
–Not associated with increased risk of microvascular disease but at substantially increased risk of macrovascular disease
•As HbA1c climbs from 34 to 48 mmol/l the {{c1::5}} year risk of T2DM increases markedly

DM Classification

•Type I Diabetes Mellitus
–In Ireland ~15,000 cases
•Type II Diabetes Mellitus
–In Ireland ~210,000 cases
•Maturity Onset Diabetes of the Young (MODY)
–2 to 5 percent of diabetes.
–Non-insulin dependent diabetes diagnosed at a young age (<25 years) with autosomal {{c1::dominant}} transmission and lack of auto-antibodies.
–Many patients are misclassified as having either type 1 or 2 diabetes.
•Diseases of the {{c1::Pancreas}}
–Cystic fibrosis, hereditary hemochromatosis, chronic pancreatitis,
•Endocrinopathies
–Cushing syndrome & acromegaly can lead to glucose dysregulation
•{{c1::Drug}}-induced diabetes
–A variety of drugs can impair glucose tolerance including corticosteroids, antipsychotics, immunosuppressants
•Gestational Diabetes Mellitus
–~2% of women develop a form of diabetes in pregnancy
–Increased risk of several adverse outcomes in pregnancy
•Pre-eclampsia, hydramnios, macrosomia, perinatal mortality, miscarriage, etc.
–Usually resolves post-{{c1::partum}} but mothers at increased risk of developing Type {{c1::II}} DM

T1DM Clinical Presentation

•Peak age is around {{c1::puberty}}, but it may present at any age
•The most common presentation is with clinical features associated with hyperglycaemia
–{{c1::Polyuria}}, {{c1::polydipsia}}, fatigue, hunger, weight loss, {{c1::blurred}} vision
•Timeframe
–Days, weeks or months
–Shorter in children, more insidious in adults
•Infection commonly {{c1::precipitates}} the initial presentation
–Fever, sore throat, cough, dysuria
•In practice, at diagnosis patients with T1DM commonly have glucose levels of {{c1::15}}-30 mmol/L and about 25% present with diabetic {{c1::ketoacidosis}}
•Results from the autoimmune destruction of the insulin-producing beta cells in the {{c1::pancreas}}.
•Antibodies are often detectable to:
–insulin - particularly in children
–{{c1::65}}-kD isoform of glutamic acid {{c1::decarboxylase}} (GAD65) - particularly in adults
–islet cells

Determinants & Risk Factors for T2DM

•{{c1::Genetics}} are a significant contributory factor
–Family history
–Ethnicity: Asians > Hispanics > Blacks > Whites
•Demographic characteristics
–Risk increases with age
–Females at higher risk than males
•Lifestyle
–Obesity (central adiposity), physical inactivity, smoking
–Too much or too little sleep
–Red meat, processed meat and sugary drinks are associated with an increased risk
–Fruits, vegetables, nuts, whole grains and olive oil are associated with a reduced risk
–Westernisation, urbanisation, modernisation
•Traditionally a disorder of aging but prevalence of obesity & T2DM in children is rising dramatically

Insulin Resistance

•An impaired biological response to insulin found in T2DM
•The pancreas makes insulin but the {{c1::tissues}} don’t respond as well to it
•Reduced insulin-stimulated glucose transport and metabolism in {{c1::adipocytes}} & skeletal {{c1::muscle}}
•Impaired {{c1::suppression}} of hepatic glucose output
•Insulin resistance is usually combined with some degree of {{c1::β}}-cell dysfunction in T2DM
•Pancreas ends up producing more insulin in order to get the same
•β-cell hyperplasia and {{c1::hypertrophy}} helps maintain normal glucose levels
•Over time the pancreas becomes {{c1::hypotrophic}} & hypoplastic & glucose levels rise because of lack of insulin produced by pancreas
•Diabetic {{c1::ketoacidosis}} usually doesn’t develop as there is some insulin which limits lipolysis

Differentiating between Type 1 and Type 2 Diabetes

•No set criteria, but based on clinical presentation & history, sometimes supported by laboratory studies
•Body habitus
–Children with T1DM usually not obese & recent hx of weight loss
–T2DM usually, but not necessarily, obese
•Age
–T1DM usually present as children
–T2DM usually present later, but with obesity may present in childhood
•Insulin resistance
–T2DM frequently have acanthosis nigricans, {{c1::hypertension}}, {{c1::dyslipidemia}} and polycystic {{c1::ovary}} syndrome
•Family history
–{{c1::10}}% in T1DM
–Up to 75-90% in T2DM

•Laboratory Tests
–Auto-{{c1::antibodies}} an indicator of T1DM, but may be present in T2DM (?slowly progressive autoimmune disease)
–Higher fasting insulin & c-peptide levels in T2DM
–MODY
•Family History in keeping with autosomal dominant inheritance
•Genetic testing can be arranged
